Leptospira santarosai serovar Shermani str. LT 821 is a pathogenic spirochete bacteria that belongs to the genus Leptospira. It is classified as a serovar within the Leptospira santarosai species, which is one of the several pathogenic Leptospira species known to cause leptospirosis in humans and animals.

The Leptospira santarosai serovar Shermani strain LT 821 is a spiral-shaped, obligately aerobic, and motile bacterium. It is typically characterized by its ability to agglutinate with specific antibodies raised against the Shermani serovar antigen. This serovar has been primarily isolated from environmental sources and animal hosts in various geographical regions.

Leptospirosis caused by Leptospira santarosai serovar Shermani can lead to a range of clinical manifestations in humans, from mild flu-like symptoms to severe forms, such as Weil's disease, which can be life-threatening if left untreated. Understanding the characteristics and epidemiology of this serovar is crucial for the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of leptospirosis in affected areas.
